newsitem.title: FRANCE: Relatives to commemorate TWA crash victims in July.
newsitem.headline: Relatives to commemorate TWA crash victims in July.

text.p: A group representing families of 230 people killed in the crash of a TWA jet outlined plans on Saturday to mark the first anniversary of the disaster in New York and called a TWA compensation offer blackmail.

The "Victims of Flight 800" said the July 17-20 commemorations would include a cathedral service and a plaque for those killed when the Paris-bound plane crashed in the Atlantic just after takeoff from New York last July 17.

Michel Breistoff, deputy head of the group, said TWA had sent letters to some families offering an immediate $75,000 in compensation to any who renounced legal action against the airline for the crash.

"It's blackmail," he said at a meeting of the group near Lille, northern France. The association represents relatives of victims from countries including the United States, France, Spain, Italy, Britain, Norway and Finland.
TWA wrote that compensation under international conventions could take many years to settle if TWA were found responsible, he said.

The cause of the crash of the Paris-bound flight is unknown. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said in May mechanical failure was probably responsible but that a missile or a bomb had not been ruled out.
"I don't like the way things are going," Breistoff said. "I think that they're trying to prepare us for a conclusion with no explanation and no one responsible."
The head of the group, Jose Cremades, said relatives were organising a service in New York's Saint Patrick's cathedral on July 17, to be attended by New York mayor Rudolph Guiliani.

"More than 500 people are also expected on Saturday morning at Calverton where the wreck of the jet has been reconstructed," Cremades said. "We will unveil a commemorative plaque with the names of the victims."
Cremades said the FBI had told relatives it would not publish conclusions of its investigation until September "because of the complexity of the inquiry".
